column1: Wollongong ( WUUL-ən-gong)
column2: informally referred to as "The Gong"
column3: is a city located in the Illawarra region of New South Wales
column4: Australia. Wollongong lies on the narrow coastal strip between the Illawarra Escarpment and the Pacific Ocean
column5: 68 kilometres (42 miles) south of central Sydney. Wollongong had an estimated urban population of 302
column6: 739 at June 2018
column7: making it the third-largest city in New South Wales after Sydney and Newcastle
column8: and the tenth-largest city in Australia. The city's current Lord Mayor is Gordon Bradbery AM who was elected in 2018.

column1: The Wollongong metropolitan area extends from Helensburgh in the north to Shell Cove in the south. It sits within the Wollongong Statistical District
column2: which covers the local authority areas of Wollongong
column3: Shellharbour and Kiama
column4: extending from the town of Helensburgh in the north
column5: to Gerroa in the south Geologically
column6: the city is located in the south-eastern part of the Sydney basin
column7: which extends from Newcastle to Nowra.Wollongong is noted for its heavy industry
column8: its port activity and the quality of its physical setting
column9: occupying a narrow coastal plain between an almost continuous chain of surf beaches and the cliffline of the rainforest-covered Illawarra escarpment. It has two cathedrals
column10: churches of many denominations and the Nan Tien Temple
column11: the largest Buddhist temple in the southern hemisphere. Wollongong has a long history of coal mining and industry. The city attracts many tourists each year
column12: and is a regional centre for the South Coast fishing industry. The University of Wollongong has around 37
column13: 000 students and is internationally recognised.The name "Wollongong" is believed to mean "seas of the South" in the local Aboriginal language
column15: referring to NSW's Southern Coast. Other meanings have been suggested

column1: == History ==
The area was originally inhabited by the Dharawal (or Turuwal) Indigenous Australians. The first Europeans to visit the area were the navigators George Bass and Matthew Flinders
column2: who landed at Lake Illawarra in 1796. The first settlers in the region were cedar cutters in the early nineteenth century
column3: followed by graziers in 1812. Charles Throsby established a stockman's hut in the area in 1815. The first land grants were made in 1816. In 1830
column4: a military barracks was constructed near the harbour. Further settlers arrived and in 1834 a town was planned. On 26 November 1834
column5: the town was first gazetted and George Brown erected the first court house. The main road down the Escarpment through Bulli Pass was built by convict labour in 1835–6
column6: although other passes were built during the 19th century as well
column7: such as O'Briens Road and Rixons Pass. By 1856 Wollongong had a population of 864.In 1858
column8: a court house was built. In 1861
column9: a horse-drawn tramway from Mount Keira to the harbour was completed. In 1862 a telegraph line was opened between Wollongong and Bellambi. In 1865
column10: the first gas supply in Wollongong was provided from a gas plant in Corrimal Street. In 1868 the extensions to the harbour were opened by Lady Belmore and named Belmore Basin. Patrick Lahiff established a coke works at Wollongong Harbour in the 1870s. He erected two beehive coke ovens between the north eastern end of the basin and Pulpit Rock. The ovens were demolished in 1892. The remains of the coke ovens were uncovered and recovered and are now preserved beneath the hill
column11: with a plaque explaining their history.

column2: the old lighthouse was completed. In 1880
column3: steam locomotives were introduced to haul coal loads from Mount Keira mine to the harbour. Gas street lighting was introduced in 1883. In 1885
column4: a new court house was erected in Market Street. Like many Australian court houses
column5: it was designed in a Classical Revival style considered appropriate for public buildings. It is now listed on the Register of the National Estate. In 1886 the first town hall was erected. The Illawarra Railway to Wollongong was completed in 1887
column6: and now continues as far south as the town of Bomaderry on the Shoalhaven River. The navigator George Bass first documented the Illawarra coal deposits in 1797. There have been many coalmines in the district. Australia's worst coal mining disaster occurred in 1902
column7: at the Mount Kembla mine when an explosion killed 94 men and boys
column9: the oldest 69. Two other men died attempting to rescue survivors. In 1908 the Wollongong District Hospital was established on Garden Hill. In 1916 the Wollongong High School was opened.

column1: Heavy industry was attracted to the region by the ready availability of coal. In 1928
column2: Hoskins
column3: later Australian Iron & Steel
column4: started a steelworks at Port Kembla
column5: a few kilometres south of Wollongong. The former Broken Hill Proprietary Company (now BHP after merging with Billiton plc) acquired AI&S in 1935
column6: but has since spun-out their steel division as a separate company
column7: now known as BlueScope. The steelworks has grown to become a world-class flat rolled steel producer
column8: operating as a fully integrated steel plant with a production of around 5 million tonnes per year. Other industries to have set up in the massive Port Kembla industrial complex—the largest single concentration of heavy industry in Australia—include a fertiliser plant
column12: a grain export shipping terminal and an industrial gases manufacturing plant.

column2: the new Wollongong Lighthouse was finished on Flagstaff Point. In 1942 Wollongong was proclaimed a City. In 1947 City of Greater Wollongong was formed. In 1954 the population of Wollongong was 90
column3: 852. In 1956 new Wollongong City Council Chambers were opened. In 1961 the Wollongong University College was established. In 1963
column4: the Wollongong Teachers College was established. In 1965 the Westfield shopping centre at Figtree opened.

column2: the railway line was electrified to Wollongong
column3: and in 1993 to Dapto. In 1986 the Wollongong Mall was completed. For a short while
column4: trams (trackless trains) were used in the mall
column5: though this ceased due to dangers involved. The mall was re-opened to traffic after the initial test but re-zoned a pedestrian area after and has remained one since.

column1: In 1987 the council chambers and library building were completed
column2: replacing the old council building at the present art gallery site. The Crown Gateway Shopping Centre was completed. Wollongong Mall was opened. In 1988
column3: the current council administration building was completed
column4: as well as the Illawarra Performing Arts Centre (IPAC)
column5: across the road on Burelli Street. IPAC was officially opened by Prince Charles and Princess Diana in 1988. A sculpture recognising Lawrence Hargrave was placed via \ helicopter on the eastern foothills of Mount Keira. In 1998 the 6000 seat Wollongong Entertainment Centre was opened.

column2: the Gateway and Crown Central mall buildings were unified as Wollongong Central and a pedestrian walkway/café was built connecting the buildings in an above ground bridge. In 2000
column3: as part of the Sydney Olympics
column4: the Olympic torch was carried through Wollongong as part of its journey. In 2001
column5: the population of Wollongong reached 181
column6: 612 people. In 2004 the Wollongong City Gallery celebrated its 25th anniversary. In 2005 Qantas established a daily air service from Wollongong to Melbourne that lasted till 2008.

column2: the library was renovated
column3: including new facilities
column4: as part of the tenth anniversary of the library's current site. Also at this time the beachfront was renovated with a new lookout and walkway upgrade. In June 2007
column5: erosion was caused via storms to the beaches
column6: the worst in 30 years.Despite the decline of traditional manufacturing and blue-collar industries due to the abandonment of protectionist economic policies in the 1980s
column7: many of these industrial installations still exist. The city's economy is
column10: thanks to diversification of economic activity including higher education
column13: residential construction and eco-friendly electricity generation; however
column14: the city's economy still relies primarily on heavy industry
column15: and will continue to in the near future.

column1: == Heritage listings ==
Wollongong has a number of heritage-listed sites
column2: including:

column1: Church Street: St Michael's Cathedral
Cliff Road: North Beach Precinct
Cliff Road and Endeavour Drive: Wollongong Harbour Precinct
87 Crown Street: 87 Crown Street
91 Crown Street: Old Wollongong East Post Office
Darling Street: Elouera House
Illawarra railway: Wollongong railway station
197 Keira Street: Regent Theatre
11 Market Street: Old Wollongong Telegraph and Post Office
31–33 Smith Street: Little Milton
== Geography ==

The city of Wollongong has a distinct geography. It lies on a narrow coastal plain flanked by the Tasman Sea to the east and a steep sandstone precipice known as the Illawarra Escarpment to the west. The coastal plain is widest in the south and narrowest in the north
column2: with the city centre located about midway. South of the city centre but within the urban area is Lake Illawarra
column3: a large lagoon.

column1: The escarpment ranges between 150 and 750 metres (490–2
column2: 460 ft) above sea level
column3: with locally famous mountains such as Mount Keira (464m)
column4: Mount Kembla (534m)
column5: Broker's Nose (440m) and Mount Murray (768m) to the south. It contains strata of coal measures
column6: and the adit entrances to many coal mines have been established along the slopes of the escarpment throughout Wollongong. Suburbia encroaches on the escarpment's lower slopes in some areas
column7: but the majority remains in a relatively natural state forested with dry sclerophyll and pockets of temperate rainforest. The escarpment is largely protected by a State Conservation Area and local scenic protection zoning
column8: and provides the visual backdrop to the city.

column1: In the north the escarpment meets the coastline
column2: and north of this the coastal road Lawrence Hargrave Drive hugs the cliff line. The unstable geology of the escarpment resulted in rockfalls
column3: forcing the closure of the road. Subsequently
column4: part of Lawrence Hargrave Drive was replaced in 2005 by the Sea Cliff Bridge just off the coast
column5: crossing the submerged rock shelf. The bridge carries both vehicular and pedestrian traffic. The Illawarra railway line must go through several tunnels to reach the Sydney metropolitan area. The Southern Freeway and Princes Highway provide alternative inland routes
column6: descending the escarpment further south at Bulli Pass or at Mount Ousley
column7: entering just north of Wollongong's city centre.

column1: To the south the plain reaches its maximum extent around Albion Park where it incorporates a large coastal saltwater lagoon called Lake Illawarra
column2: separated from the Pacific Ocean by a long sandy spit.

column1: The coastal strip consists of highly fertile alluvium
column2: which made Wollongong so attractive to agriculturists in the nineteenth century. It contains many hills including the foothills of the escarpment's lower slopes
column3: and while these generally do not exceed one hundred metres in height they give much of the city an undulating character. The coastal strip is traversed by several short but flood-prone and fast-flowing streams and creeks such as Fairy Creek (Para Creek)
column4: Cabbage Tree Creek
column5: Allans Creek
column6: Nostaw Ravine

column1: The coastline consists of many beaches characterised by fine pale gold-coloured sands; however
column2: these beaches are sometimes interrupted by prominent and rocky headlands
column3: such as Tego Rock
column4: jutting into the sea. In places these headlands have been excavated or extended to create artificial harbours at Wollongong
column5: Port Kembla
column6: Shellharbour and Kiama. Just off the coast south of Wollongong centre
column8: lies a group of five islands known collectively as The Five Islands. The islands are a wildlife refuge.

column1: === Inner city ===
The inner city area includes the suburbs of Wollongong and North Wollongong
column2: extending from Fairy Creek in the north
column3: west to include the Wollongong Hospital
column4: and south to the Greenhouse Park. At the 2016 census
column5: the suburb of Wollongong had a population of 18
column6: 442.The CBD is a major commercial hub containing many department stores and specialty shops
column8: and entertainment venues. It is centred on the Crown Street Mall and Wollongong Central
column9: and approximates the area bounded by Market
column11: and Burelli streets and the railway line. Surrounding the CBD lies a mixture of parks
column14: houses and multi-story residential units. Multi-story housing is evident particularly on Smith's Hill
column16: reflecting the popularity of combining inner-city living
column17: coastal views and a beachside lifestyle.

column1: To the east of the city lies Flagstaff Point
column2: a rocky headland with eroded low cliffs topped by a grassy hill. The northern side of the point was excavated by convict labour to form Belmore Basin. This was later extended with the northern breakwater to create Wollongong Harbour. The area is the site of a historic colonial fort
column3: several restored cannons and two lighthouses
column4: a feature peculiar to the east coast of Australia. The older Wollongong Breakwater Lighthouse located at the harbour entrance was made of wrought iron plates in 1871 and has become an icon of the city. The newer Wollongong Head Lighthouse was constructed in 1936 atop the Flagstaff Hill and is still used in the early 21st century. Belmore Basin houses the commercial fishing fleet and Fisherman's Co-op
column5: while the main harbour shelters private vessels.

column1: The main beaches of central Wollongong are North Wollongong (or simply North) Beach
column2: extending from the harbour up to the Fairy lagoon and Puckeys Estate Reserve
column3: and Wollongong City Beach
column4: extending south from Flagstaff Point and into Coniston Beach.

column1: === Climate ===
Wollongong has an oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb)
column2: but with humid subtropical (Cfa) influences as its warmest month mean of 21.9 °C (71.4 °F)

column1: is just below the subtropical isotherm of 22 °C (72 °F). The highest recorded temperature is 44.1 °C on 1 January 2006
column2: and the lowest 0.8 °C on 27 July 1986. Annually
column3: Wollongong receives 107.4 clear days.Rainfall is fairly evenly distributed throughout the seasons
column4: with a bias to the first half of the year. It is often associated with orographic lift caused by the escarpment. A significant flood event occurred on 18 August 1998 when Wollongong recorded 316 mm of rainfall (the nearby suburb of Mt Ousley recorded in excess of 445 mm)
column5: mostly falling in a 3-hour period. Wollongong also experiences thunderstorms during the warmer months bringing lightning
column6: heavy rain and occasionally hail.

column1: July and August are known as the windy months
column2: with westerly gales that can gust at over 100 km/h.

column1: == Demographics ==
The Wollongong metropolitan area includes the suburbs
column2: outlying towns and rural localities stretching from Helensburgh in the north to Kiama in the south. According to the 2016 census
column3: it had a population of 285
column4: 678 people.

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 2.9% of the population.
74.1% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 4.2%
column2: North Macedonia 1.3%
column3: China 1.1%
column4: Italy 1.1% and New Zealand 1.0%.

column1: 80.4% of people spoke only English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Macedonian 2.2%
column2: Italian 1.5%
column3: Mandarin 1.1%
column4: Arabic 1.1% and Spanish 0.8%.

column1: The most common responses for religion were No Religion 27.2%
column2: Catholic 26.1% and Anglican 17.9%.

column1: 4.2% of employed people worked in Hospitals (except Psychiatric Hospitals). Other major industries of employment included Aged Care Residential Services 2.6%
column2: Higher Education 2.6%
column3: Supermarket and Grocery Stores 2.4% and Cafes and Restaurants 2.4%.It is the third largest city in New South Wales and the tenth largest in Australia. Using 2006 ABS geography
column4: around 89% of the statistical district's population reside in the built-up urban centre extending from Clifton to Shell Cove.The following table includes selected 2006 census figures for these areas
column5: together with those for the central suburb of Wollongong.

column1: Wollongong is continuing to grow with a population growth of 3.1% for the period 2001 to 2006
column2: although the supply of new residential land is limited by the geography particularly in the northern suburbs. The west Dapto area is a major centre of future growth with plans for 19
column3: 000 new dwellings and 50
column4: 000 people within 40 years. New residential areas are also being developed further south around the Albion Park
column5: Shell Cove and Kiama areas.

column1: Wollongong has a distinctly multicultural population. Many migrants were attracted to the area by the job opportunities at the Port Kembla steelworks in the post-war period
column2: and settled in surrounding suburbs such as Cringila
column3: Warrawong and Coniston. By 1966 about 60% of the wage earners at the Australian Iron and Steel steelworks were born overseas coming from over 100 different countries. These included British
column4: Irish
column5: Macedonians
column6: Spaniards
column17: Chileans and Brazilians. With the end of the White Australia policy these were followed by Indo-Chinese refugees in the 1970s
column24: Koreans and Pacific Islanders in the 1980s and 1990s. The university continues to attract students and staff from all over the world

column1: Around 20
column2: 000 people commute daily to jobs in Sydney by road and rail
column3: making it one of the busiest commuter corridors in Australia.

column1: == Education ==
=== Tertiary and further education ===
There are two campuses of the Illawarra Institute of TAFE. The Wollongong Campus is the network's largest campus
column2: and it offers a variety of courses.

column1: Wollongong has one university
column2: the University of Wollongong
column3: which was formerly part of the University of New South Wales. The University was awarded the "Australian University of the Year" in two consecutive years (1999–2000
column4: 2000–2001) by the Good Universities Guide
column5: and is internationally recognised. It has two main campuses: the primary campus on Northfields Avenue
column6: and the Innovation Campus on Squires Way. The University's Sydney Business School also has a secondary campus in Sydney.

column1: === Schools ===
Wollongong has a number of primary and high schools
column2: including public
column3: denominational and independent. Specialist high schools include the selective Smith's Hill High School
column4: the Illawarra Sports High School
column5: The Illawarra Grammar School
column6: St Mary Star of the Sea College (all-girls Catholic high school)
column7: Edmund Rice College (all-boys Catholic high school)
column8: Holy Spirit College (Co-educational Catholic high school)
column10: Illawarra Christian School and the Wollongong High School of the Performing Arts.

column1: == Media ==
Wollongong has one daily newspaper
column2: The Illawarra Mercury published and issued Monday to Saturday by Australian Community Media (ACM). Additionally
column3: ACM publishes several free community newspapers including the Advertiser incorporating Lake Times and Kiama Independent.Wollongong and the Illawarra region are serviced by three commercial television networks – WIN Television
column4: Prime7 and Southern Cross Nine. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) also broadcast television services to Wollongong. In addition to these channels
column5: ten new channels broadcasting in are also available in Wollongong and the greater Illawarra region. These channels include ABC HD
column6: ABC Comedy
column19: 10 Peach and SBS Viceland. In some areas it is also possible to pick up Sydney channels. Subscription Television service Foxtel (formerly Austar) is also available via satellite.

column1: Of the three main commercial networks:
WIN Television airs a half-hour local WIN News each weeknight at 6pm
column2: produced and broadcast from the network's headquarters in the city

column1: Southern Cross Nine airs a regional New South Wales edition of Nine News from Sydney each weeknight at 6pm
column2: featuring opt-outs for Wollongong and the Illawarra.

column1: Prime7 airs short local news and weather updates throughout the day
column2: produced and broadcast from its Canberra studios.The region receives five ABC radio services – ABC Illawarra 97.3FM
column3: Triple J 98.9
column4: and Radio National 1431 AM
column5: ABC Classic FM 95.7 and Newsradio 90.9FM. There are two commercial radio stations i98FM 98.1 and WAVE FM 96.5 – formerly 2WL
column6: and two community radio stations Vox FM 106.9 and Christian broadcaster 94.1 FM.

column1: == Transport ==
=== Road ===
The main road connecting Wollongong is the M1 Princes Motorway (formerly the F6). The motorway
column2: part of National Route 1
column3: descends the escarpment via Mount Ousley Road to enter the city near the University of Wollongong and exits at its southern fringe. A second freeway
column4: Memorial Drive (formerly the Northern Distributor)
column5: continues northward from the university to connect Wollongong's northern suburbs
column6: Bulli Pass and the scenic Lawrence Hargrave Drive. The Illawarra Highway connects Wollongong's southern suburbs to the Southern Highlands via Macquarie Pass.

column1: === Rail ===

Wollongong is served by the Illawarra railway line. Passenger rail services on this line connect the centres of Nowra and Kiama to the south and Sydney to the north. A branch line connects suburbs between the CBD and Port Kembla. A passenger rail service connecting Wollongong to the Southern Highlands has since been replaced with a coach service. Wollongong railway station is the city's main train station
column2: and serves Wollongong's CBD.

column1: Freight services connect Sydney markets with Port Kembla and the Manildra Group factory at Bomaderry. The Southern Highlands line is used primarily for freight
column2: providing an important bypass for Sydney's congested rail network.

column1: Route services in Wollongong are provided by Premier Illawarra and Dion's Bus Service who also provide school/charter services together with some other companies. Wollongong railway station serves as the network's hub. Services connect Wollongong suburbs to Shellharbour
column2: Lake Illawarra and the Royal National Park. There is also a Free Shuttle Bus service that connects the CBD
column3: University and the suburbs of North Wollongong
column4: Fairy Meadow and Gwynneville.

column1: Wollongong is serviced by Shellharbour Airport
column2: also known as Illawarra Regional Airport and Wollongong Airport. The Airport is located in Albion Park Rail
column3: 18km south of Wollongong CBD in the Shellharbour City LGA.

column1: Regular Public Transport (RPT) air services to Melbourne (Essendon) and Brisbane airports were recommenced by Fly Corporate in 2018
column2: following the cancellation of previous services offered by JetGo and QantasLink. Fly Corporate operates 34 seat SAAB 340B turboprop aircraft.

column1: There are multiple air charter businesses including NSW Air
column2: EliteJet and Touchdown Helicopters. The Historical Aircraft Restoration Society (HARS) is also based at the airport.

column1: == Culture ==
=== Arts ===

Wollongong maintains an active arts scene. In the area of music the city is home to various music and jazz ensembles. The Wollongong Conservatorium of Music provides musical tuition for instruments and voice in classical
column2: jazz and contemporary styles. It is one of the largest regional conservatoriums in Australia and located in the historic Gleniffer Brae Manor House
column3: part of the Wollongong Botanic Gardens.

column1: The local professional theatre company
column2: Merrigong Theatre Company
column3: is located at the Illawarra Performing Arts Centre. Merrigong also manages the city's key civic and community venue
column4: the Wollongong Town Hall
column5: and presents a diverse range of events in the heart of the city. Other local theatre groups include The Arcadians
column6: The Phoenix Theatre and Wollongong Workshop Theatre.

column1: The annual Wollongong Eisteddfod showcases local talent in music
column2: theatre and dance.

column1: The Wollongong City Gallery houses a significant collection of the art of the Illawarra
column2: contemporary Australian
column3: Aboriginal and Asian art.

column1: The popular 1990s stoner rock band Tumbleweed were formed and based in Wollongong
column2: as are Surf-Rock duo Hockey Dad.

column1: Yours and Owls Festival is an annual music festival that attracts 12
column2: 000 people and features the best up and coming Australian and international bands.

column1: Cyrus Villanueva
column2: winner of the seventh season of The X Factor Australia
column3: was born and raised in Wollongong.Wollongong also hosts Wonderwalls
column4: an annual street art festival featuring local and internationally acclaimed street artists.

column1: === Entertainment and Nightlife ===
Entertainment venues include the Crown Street Mall
column2: many restaurants and cafes
column3: the town cinemas and the Illawarra Performing Arts Centre. Adjacent to WIN Stadium
column4: the home ground of the NRL team St. George Illawarra Dragons
column5: is the WIN Entertainment Centre: a multipurpose venue which hosts concerts and sporting events (including Southern Stars
column6: basketball and motocross stunt shows). There are numerous city nightclubs
column7: pubs & registered clubs; Including The Illawarra Master Builders Club
column8: The Grand Hotel (back to its original name
column9: after being called Cooney's for a few years)
column14: and The North Wollongong Hotel. Most suburbs also have their own hotels

column1: === Recreation ===
Wollongong has 17 seasonally-patrolled local beaches: Stanwell Park
column2: Coalcliff
column3: Scarborough/Wombarra
column4: Coledale
column5: Austinmer
column6: Thirroul
column19: skimboarding are common activities. The Wollongong to Thirroul Bike Track
column20: a thirteen kilometre Heart Foundation walking/biking pathway which runs northwards adjacent to the Illawarra coastline starting at Wollongong Beach
column23: skaters and bicycle riders. Bushwalking on nearby Mount Keira and Mount Kembla
column24: and motorbike riding at the Motocross Track on the escarpment west of Wollongong

column1: Wollongong has many parks. In the city centre is McCabe Park
column2: featuring a playground
column3: the local youth centre
column4: a war memorial
column5: community hall
column6: a sculpture called "Nike" and a brick amphitheatre. Lang Park
column8: has a number of shelters built in the 1950s. These were subject for demolition but were saved by a community vote. Stuart Park
column9: to the coastal north of the city but south of Fairy Lagoon and Puckeys Estate Reserve
column10: is well known as a landing spot for skydivers as well as a place for outdoor recreation and social gatherings. Stuart Park is also distinctive for its Norfolk Island Pines
column11: planted during the North Wollongong tourism boom in the 1920s. J.J.Kelly Park to the south is used by circuses
column12: as well as a protected area of creek leading to the Greenhouse Park north of the Port Kembla Steelworks
column13: containing a revegetated area of once waste and a lookout
column14: as well as the small remnants of Tom Thumb Lagoon
column15: which once stretched north to Swan Street. Beaton Park in Gwynneville is home to Tennis Wollongong and the Leisure Centre with an athletics complex

column1: === Sport ===
==== Rugby League ====

The St George Illawarra Dragons Rugby league club represents the city in the National Rugby League (NRL) competition. The club was formed in a merger between the St. George Dragons and the Illawarra Steelers in 1999
column2: and continues to play some home games at WIN Stadium. They won the 2010 NRL Grand Final against the Sydney Roosters. Prior to the merger the Illawarra Steelers had represented the area in the New South Wales Rugby League premiership and NRL between 1982 and 1998. Rugby League has been played in Wollongong since 1911
column3: and the area has produced at least 41 international players. At the local level league continues to have a strong following with a number of teams playing in the Illawarra Rugby League and Group 7 Rugby League competitions.

column1: The Illawarra Cutters represent the Illawarra region in the New South Wales Cup and the Harold Matthews Cup.
==== Other sports ====

The city does not have a senior cricket team representing it. Ireland captain Trent Johnston grew up in Dapto and played for New South Wales before leaving for Ireland. Australian internationals and New South Wales players Brett and Shane Lee were raised in Oak Flats and played for the local cricket club Oak Flat Rats.
The Illawarra Lions represent the region in the Sydney AFL competition (as the only non-sydney base side).The Illawarriors are a rugby union club based in the Illawarra
column2: who contest the Shute Shield NSW club competition. The club play some of their home games at WIN Stadium.

column1: The Illawarra Hawks basketball team play in the National Basketball League and are the only NBL club (as of 2019/20 season) to have competed in every season since the league's inception in 1979. Home games are played at the WIN Entertainment Centre
column2: known as "The Sandpit" in the NBL.Wollongong FC is the region's football (soccer) club who compete in the New South Wales Premier League. Scott Chipperfield
column3: a Wollongong native who became a professional football player in Europe
column4: along with Tim Cahill
column5: has recently expressed an interest in being involved in a Wollongong football club in the A-League
column6: as well as the Sydney club playing some promotional games in Wollongong. Great South Football is a consortium preparing the Illawarra's South Coast A-League bid. In late 2008
column7: the club folded due to debt incurred over the past season. It is proposed that a new community-based entity will take on the Football NSW licence previously held by Wollongong FC.The Illawarra Cycling Club holds road cycle races almost every week of the year. During the summer
column8: velodrome racing is also promoted at the Unanderra Velodrome on the Princes Highway. A recent focus within the club has seen a shift to encompass a stronger emphasis on youth development programs alongside its already strong commitment to competitive under 19's
column9: 23's and adult road racing. The club is represented at a state and national level regularly and has had several riders compete at international levels.The Gong Scorpions are the local Floorball team from the Wollongong area. The Club plays socially at the Wollongong University and has recently been re-established in order to compete in the NSW Elite Series.Baseball has been played in the region with structured competitions conducted since 1938. The Illawarra District Baseball Association was the governing body from this year until 1991 when the Illawarra Baseball League was created.

column1: The Illawarra Junior Baseball League was inaugurated in 1984 to accommodate a growing number of juniors that peaked at around 950 players in 1995.
Eight regional clubs from four Local Government Areas play in the I B L.
A regional club
column2: the Illawarra Flame Baseball Club
column3: fielded teams in four grades in the New South Wales Baseball League Sydney Major League from 1994 to 2007. The first grade team made the Grand Final in their inaugural season. The Club won a total of four premierships while participating.

column1: The IFBC played their inaugural games against the All Kawasaki Baseball Club in August 1994 the games being the first sporting exchange between the Sister Cities
column2: Wollongong and Kawasaki.

column1: The Wollongong Whales compete against Bondi Icebergs Winter Swimming Club
column2: South Maroubra Dolphins Winter Swimming Club
column3: Cronulla Polar Bears Winter Swimming Club
column4: Maroubra Seals Winter Swimming Club
column5: Coolangatta Surf Life Saving Club
column6: Clovelly Eskimos Winter Swimming Club
column8: Coogee Penguins Winter Swimming Club and Cottesloe Crabs in the Winter Swimming Association of Australia Championships.Otis Jones is the regions superstar wrestler with an International following.

column1: Other popular sports in the Illawarra include golf
column2: rock climbing
column3: surfing
column4: cup stacking
column5: triathlon and mountain biking.

column1: In the book Quidditch Through the Ages by J. K. Rowling
column2: the Wollongong Warriors are listed as one of Australia's quidditch teams. They have a rivalry with the Thundelarra Thunderers
column3: and are the inventors of the Wollongong Shimmy
column4: a high-speed zig-zag move designed to confuse and distract opposing Chasers. Wollongong Warriors is now a real club in Australian Quidditch Association
column5: a Muggle quidditch league.

column1: Wollongong will be hosting the UCI Road World Championships in 2022.
